text:
Raskolnikov couldn’t remember the guy’s face, and even now it didn’t ring a bell. But he realized that he had almost lost it over something so small. 😳 This guy could only talk about the flat and the blood stains. Porfiry had nothing solid either—just a bunch of psychological games that could backfire. No hard evidence. If nothing else pops up (and it better not!), what could they really do to him? How could they even charge him if they arrested him? Plus, Porfiry only just heard about the flat; he didn’t know anything before.

“Did you tell Porfiry I was there?” Raskolnikov blurted out, hit by a lightbulb moment.

“What Porfiry?” 

“The head detective?”

“Yeah. The porters didn’t go, but I did.”

“Today?”

“I got there two minutes before you. I heard everything—how he was messing with you.”

“Where? What? When?”

“In the next room. I was there the whole time.”

“What? So you were the surprise? How did that even happen? Seriously!”

“I saw the porters didn’t want to do what I asked,” the man started. “They said it was too late and maybe you’d be mad that we didn’t come on time. I was annoyed, and I…”

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Raskolnikov grapples with the psychological implications of his actions and the potential consequences of being discovered.
